pull.title: IBD using chainwork instead of height and not using header timestamps
pull.body:
This introduces a 'minimum chain work' chainparam which is intended
 to be the known amount of work in the chain for the network at the
 time of software release.  If you don't have this much work, you're
 not yet caught up.
    
This is used instead of the count of blocks test from checkpoints.

This criteria is trivial to keep updated as there is no element of
 subjectivity, trust, or position dependence to it. It is also a more
 reliable metric of sync status than a block count.

This is the first step in a larger change to eliminate checkpoints
 completely, but it's independently a good idea.

This PR makes IsInitialBlockDownload no longer use header-only timestamps.

This avoids a corner case (mostly visible on testnet) where bogus
 headers can keep nodes in IsInitialBlockDownload.

events.body:
utACK f3f8d2e

Nit: `GetTotalBlocksEstimate` is no longer used (only in tests). Feel free to remove that now.
utACK - certainly a more reliable metric.

events.message:
IBD check uses minimumchain work instead of checkpoints.

This introduces a 'minimum chain work' chainparam which is intended
 to be the known amount of work in the chain for the network at the
 time of software release.  If you don't have this much work, you're
 not yet caught up.

This is used instead of the count of blocks test from checkpoints.

This criteria is trivial to keep updated as there is no element of
subjectivity, trust, or position dependence to it. It is also a more
reliable metric of sync status than a block count.

Remove GetTotalBlocksEstimate and checkpoint tests that test nothing.

GetTotalBlocksEstimate is no longer used and it was the only thing
 the checkpoint tests were testing.

Since checkpoints are on their way out it makes more sense to remove
 the test file than to cook up a new pointless test.

IsInitialBlockDownload no longer uses header-only timestamps.

This avoids a corner case (mostly visible on testnet) where bogus
 headers can keep nodes in IsInitialBlockDownload.

issue.title: Ignore getheaders prior to passing all checkpoints.
issue.body: An improvement over #6172. Fixes #6971 rather than bypasses it as #6974 did, and reduces overloading of whitelisting.

events.body: I wonder if this should be backported to 0.13.2, as it fixes a visible issue on testnet.

issue.title: Use a proper factory for creating chainparams
issue.body:
2 global variables are currently enough for basechainparams and CChainParams, but we're
using N + 1  globals instead. Although N is likely to remain 3 for the
foreseeable future ~~(and not many people seemed interested in turning N
into infinite in #6382)~~ I believe segwit was an example on how starting a new testchain can be very useful and anything that makes that easier is potentially valuable.

Traceability: Replaces #6907. 
Changes from final non-merged #6907:
- [X] Of course, there were new uses of CChainParams& Params(std::string)
- [X] post-segwit: UpdateRegtestBIP9Parameters is replaced with
  UpdateBIP9Parameters since we don't have a separate global for
  regtest anymore. An additional assert/error could be added if we
  wanted to restrict its usage beyond regtest, bit I don't think the
  restriction makes sense. Remember that Params() now returns a const ref and init.cpp was the only context was the only context where UpdateRegtestBIP9Parameters was called from.
- [X] post-C++11: s/boost::scoped_ptr/std::unique_ptr/ as in #8629
- [X] Return a std::unique_ptr<CChainParams> directly instead of a CChainParams*
- [X] testChainParams could be confused as meaning params from testnet (changed to chainParams)
- [X] Changes to checkpoint tests no longer required after #9053

events.body: utACK e141beb6a9816b7e1e680fb0a8bae16d42a3e557 very clean to read commit by commit.

issue.title: Testchains: Introduce custom chain whose constructor...
issue.body:
...reads from runtime params and simplify the creation of partitioned chains by simply generating different gensis block hashes from a given custom name.

It also allows to customize any chain param in these custom chains (but not the other chains).

Dependencies:

- [ ] Testschains: Many regtests with different genesis and default datadir #17037
- [ ] Tests: Chainparams: Make regtest almost fully customizable #17032
- [ ] Tests: Use self.chain instead of 'regtest' in all current tests #16681
- [x] Preparations for more testchains #16680
- [x] Use a proper factory for creating chainparams #8855
~~- [ ] Really don't validate genesis block #9102~~
- [x] Introduce an ArgsManager class encapsulating cs_args, mapArgs and mapMultiArgs #9494
- [x] QA: segwit.py: s/find_unspent/find_spendable_utxo/ #11869
- [x] Refactor: One CBaseChainParams should be enough #12128

 Other features:
- [x] Uses a custom chain for all python tests.
- [X] Create new testchains with different genesis hashes at will.
- [X] Load chainparams from ~~separated~~ file or command line. (file left for later, see https://github.com/jtimon/bitcoin/tree/b16-new-testnet-file )
- [X] New chains are neither orange, blue nor green: they're purple and have your custom chain petname shown in the GUI.
- Extra context: some people asked for signed blocks but that's way more disruptive and this is already review-thirsty (see #9177 ).

issue.title: [0.13 Backport] IBD using chainwork instead of height and not using header timestamp (#9053)
issue.body:
This is a backport of PR #9053 -- we passed on backporting it right after it was merged, but it's been in master for over a month now with no issue.

This resolves some frequent annoying misbehavior on testnet (in theory the problems it solves are also possible on mainnet but aren't likely there without miner funny business).

issue.title: Backport "assumed valid blocks" feature from Bitcoin 0.13
issue.body:
This PR backports the "assumed valid blocks" feature from Bitcoin 0.13+ as already discussed in https://www.dash.org/forum/threads/backporting-bitcoin-0-13-performance-improvements.15612/

The PR includes multiple backported commits and 1 custom commit.

**EDIT: As requested, I added original commit IDs to the description. Also, I added a few more commits as I realized that I should not have selected commits on naive commit level but on PR level. I reordered the commits based on PRs and marked the new commits with NEW**

From original PR https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9053
1. "IBD check uses minimumchain work instead of checkpoints" (original commit: fd46136dfaf68a7046cf7b8693824d73ac6b1caf)
This one introduced the nMinimumChainWork chainparam which is needed by the assumed valid blocks feature.
I updated the nMinimumChainWork param for both the Dash mainnet and the testnet.
2. **NEW** "Remove GetTotalBlocksEstimate and checkpoint tests that test nothing." (original commit: 2082b5574cec783f4ff99941492d92e05680b293)
3. **NEW** "IsInitialBlockDownload no longer uses header-only timestamps." (original commit: e141beb6a9816b7e1e680fb0a8bae16d42a3e557)

From original PR https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/10345
1. "Delay parallel block download until chain has sufficient work" (original commit: e2652002b6011f793185d473f87f1730c625593b)
As written in the forum post, I noticed that block headers and blocks are downloaded at the same time. When the node tries to figure out if an incoming block is an ancestor of the assumed valid block, it needs all the headers up until the assumed valid block. This means, it will always trigger full validation until the required headers are downloaded. As headers and blocks are downloaded at the same time, the headers download is slowed down quite a bit, so it's better to use full bandwidth for headers before we start the actual block download. This commits delays the block download.
2. **NEW** Add timeout for headers sync (original commit: 76f74811c44b5119d5c19364b0594d423248ac0e)

Custom commits:
1. "Add consensusParams to FindNextBlocksToDownload"
I had to add the consensusParams argument as it is not there yet due to other missing backports. This may result in minor conflicts later when other stuff is backported.

From original PR https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9484
1. "Introduce assumevalid setting to skip presumed valid scripts." (original commit: e440ac7ef3b6f3ad1cd8fc7027cece40413202d9)
This is the actual feature being backported. It introduces the "-assumevalid" cli argument and the defaultAssumeValid chainparam. I've updated defaultAssumeValid for both the Dash mainnet and testnet.

**EDIT: The above commits miss a new testcase being added in the original PR. I'm gonna handle this while fixing the other failing tests.** 

I would like to ask a few reviewers to verify the values used for nMinimumChainWork and defaultAssumeValid, to make sure I chose correct values. This can be done with your own full node and the debug console. I used block 721000 on mainnet and 251000 on testnet. To check if I used correct values, you could for example use the command "getblockhash 721000" and then "getblock XXX" with the result of getblockhash. getblock will also tell you the chainwork of that block.

Currently, it's hard to see the progress of the synchronization with this PR applied, as headers synching is not shown yet. It looks like nothing is happening for some time, until the actual block download starts. To see progress, it's needed to enter the debug console and use "getblockchaininfo", which will tell you how many headers are downloaded.

The current Bitcoin code already fixes this with some enhancements to the Qt wallet. The next step would be to backport some of these changes to enhance the user experience.

issue.title: WIP: Work in Progress
issue.body:
- removes `nNonce` from block header ([ADR-17](https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e-docs/blob/master/adrs/2018-11-02-ADR-17%20No%20Nonce%20or%20Extra%20Nonce.md)) 
- adds segwit merkle tree root to block header ([ADR-3](https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e-docs/blob/master/adrs/2018-09-04-ADR-3%20Unit-e%20Block%20Header%20to%20include%20SegWit%20Merkle%20Root.md), fixes https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/issues/68)
- enables segwit by default
- swaps Proof-of-Work with Proof-of-Stake (fixes https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/issues/69, completes Milestone https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/milestone/2)
- replaces the stillborns https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/pull/88, https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/pull/189, https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/pull/107, https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/pull/109
- removes the concept of _minimum chain work_ as there is no work (a few TODOs to check crucial places are left, IMHO finalization and a smart fork-choice-rule should be able to immitate the concept of minimum chain work). This check was introduced for the initial block download (IBD) in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9053
- along with that removes the `-minchainwork` cli opt
- removes `getblocktemplate` RPC call (partially closes https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e/issues/16). `getblocktemplate` was specified in [BIP 22](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0022.mediawiki) and [BIP 23](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0023.mediawiki). No Proof-of-Work -> No Mining -> No Pooled Mining -> No BIP 22 and No BIP 23 (will add to https://github.com/dtr-org/unit-e-docs/blob/master/bip-removal-reference.md)
- provides a `GenesisBlockBuilder` that can be used to create arbitrary genesis blocks (fixes #10)
- genesis block is created with native P2WKH transactions (fixes #48)

## Unit Tests

- [ ] blockassembleradapter_tests*

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,6 +47,7 @@ Update the following:
 - `doc/README.md` and `doc/README_windows.txt`
 - `doc/Doxyfile`: `PROJECT_NUMBER` contains the full version
 - `contrib/gitian-descriptors/*.yml`: usually one'd want to do this on master after branching off the release - but be sure to at least do it before a new major release
+- `src/chainparams.cpp`: periodically update nMinimumChainWork with information from the getblockchaininfo rpc.
comments.body: Nit: I think you want to move this up to the section " Before every minor and major release:"
Where is this number from please?
@rebroad It is mentioned in the doc change in this very pull...
You can just run the getblockchaininfo rpc per the instructions and observe that its a number equal to or greater than that in order to verify it. :)
Any particular reason to use GetTime here over GetAdjustedTime?
